messages.content:
Based on this resume, give the user the information they need: 
# Core Competencies

Shirpa Muthu


Houston, Texas • shirpa.muthu@gmail.com • (346)-901-7266 • www.linkedin.com/in/shirpamuthu


Professional Summary
Instructional Designer & Learning Strategist with expertise in end-to-end project management, scalable eLearning
development, and data-driven learning solutions. Proven track record of designing high-impact training programs that
improve performance, compliance, and operational efficiency. Adept at managing cross-functional teams, optimizing
LMS ecosystems, and leveraging Agile methodologies to deliver projects under budget and ahead of schedule. Passionate
about accessibility, UX-driven design, and continuous improvement in learning environments.

CORE COMPETENCIES
* Project & Program Management
* Instructional Design (ADDIE, SAM, Bloom's Taxonomy)
* eLearning Development (Articulate 360, Adobe Captivate, Camtasia)
* LMS Administration & Analytics
* Stakeholder & Vendor Management
* Process Improvement
* UX Design for Learning (Wireframing, Prototyping)
* Data-Driven Decision Making (Kirkpatrick Model, ROI Analysis)


Experience

Scoot Education	Houston, Texas
Educator | Curriculum Developer	Feb 2025 - Present
* Curriculum Design: Developed differentiated lesson plans aligned with competency-based assessments,
improving student proficiency by 22%.
* Data-Driven Adjustments: Used formative assessments to refine instruction, reducing knowledge gaps by 18%.

Lumiere Systems			Houston, Texas
Instructional Designer | Learning Program Manager	Jan 2023 - Dec 2024

*Led enterprise-wide L&D initiatives, optimizing training delivery for 500+ employees across technical and operational
teams.*

* Project Management: Spearheaded a training modernization program, managing scope, budget ($250K), and
timelines, delivering all milestones 12% under budget and ahead of schedule.
* Stakeholder Collaboration: Partnered with 12+ department leads and 20+ SMEs to redesign onboarding, sales
enablement, and compliance training, reducing ramp-up time by 25%.
* eLearning Development: Designed 30+ interactive modules (Articulate Storyline, Captivate) with simulations,
gamification, and scenario-based learning, increasing completion rates by 60% and knowledge retention by 42%.
* Process Improvement: Streamlined content review cycles, cutting development time by 30% through standardized
templates and feedback loops.
* LMS Optimization: Migrated legacy content to a cloud-based LMS, improving accessibility (WCAG 2.1 AA
compliance) and reducing helpdesk tickets by 35%.

University of Houston			Houston, Texas
Learning Experience (LX/UX) Design Director	Jan 2023 - Dec 2024
* Process Improvement: Applied Six Sigma to streamline training workflows, reducing redundancies and
improving training delivery efficiency by 28%.
* Workshop Facilitation: Designed and led 15+ UX workshops, incorporating feedback loops that increased
participant satisfaction scores from 3.8 to 4.6/5.
Volunteer work

Houston Tamil Church	Houston, Texas
UX Designer	Jan 2025 - Present
* This section can be formatted similarly to the Experience section, or you can omit descriptions for activities.
* If this section is more relevant to the opportunity you are applying for, consider moving this above your
Experience section.
Education

University of Houston (Cullen College of Engineering)			Houston, Texas
Bachelor of Science | Specialization: Innovation Engineering & Systems Design
Leadership Program: Technology Leadership & Innovation Management (TLIM)
* Applied Innovation Engineering: Designed a scalable training framework for organizational processes, reducing
redundancies by 30% in a capstone project. (Relevant to Amazon's "Invent and Simplify" principle.)
* TLIM Program: Developed leadership skills in cross-functional collaboration, lean process improvement,
and data-driven decision-making--directly applicable to Amazon's "Earn Trust" and "Dive Deep" principles.
* Systems Design Focus: Researched and prototyped human-centered learning solutions, integrating UX principles
with instructional design (e.g., created a user-tested microlearning prototype with 92% usability satisfaction)


Certifications

* Innovation Engineering Blue Belt
* Introduction to Logistics - Chartered Institute of Logistics and Transport (SA)
* Various FEMA Certifications
* Communication - Southwest Airlines
Technical Proficiencies

* Microsoft Office Suite (Word, PowerPoint, Excel, Outlook)
* SharePoint & Teams for Internal Communications
* Adobe Creative Suite (Photoshop, Illustrator, Premiere Pro)
* LMS & E-learning Tools (Articulate Storyline, Camtasia, Captivate)
* Data Analysis & Reporting Tools
* Policy & Training Program Development
You are not allowed to make up information.
You are an expert at analyzing technical resumes. Make your answers as short as possible. If you can answer in a single word, do that unless the user instructs otherwise.
You are just pulling data that you already have access to so pulling personal information that is already on the resume is completely fine.
If you can't find an answer or it's not provided/listed, just put NULL. 
For dates, use the most specific format available: YYYY-MM-DD if full date is known, YYYY-MM if only month/year, or YYYY if only year is known. For current positions, use 'Present' as the end date. If a date is completely unknown, output NULL.
When identifying skills, software languages, applications, and hardware, prioritize accuracy over standardization. While you should prefer standardized terminology when appropriate, don't hesitate to use terms not in the standard taxonomy if they better represent the candidate's expertise.

SKILLS TAXONOMY REFERENCE:

## IT Project & Portfolio Management
Relevant job titles: IT Project Manager
Skills in this category: Project Management

BACKGROUND INFORMATION:

You are analyzing a professional resume for the first time in this conversation.
Focus on understanding the candidate's complete professional profile including their technical and non-technical capabilities.
For technical candidates, pay close attention to languages, frameworks, hardware, and project types.
For non-technical candidates, focus on business skills, functions performed, and transferable skills.
Always provide a professional category for every candidate - never return NULL for categories.

SKILLS TAXONOMY INTERPRETATION GUIDANCE:
The skills taxonomy provides standardized categorization of technical skills for this resume.
Use this taxonomy to guide your analysis of programming languages, software applications, and hardware.
When identifying skills, prefer terminology from the appropriate taxonomy categories, but don't hesitate to use different terms when they better represent the candidate's expertise.
Align your responses with the skill categories most relevant to this candidate's profile.
For software languages, applications, and hardware, use the taxonomy as a reference but feel empowered to include technologies that aren't listed if they are clearly important to the candidate's profile.
Example: If the taxonomy lists 'Java' but the resume shows extensive React.js experience, it's appropriate to list React.js even if it's not in the taxonomy.
Balance standardization with accuracy - prioritize capturing the candidate's true expertise over strict adherence to the taxonomy.
IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary technical category. These must be different from each other. If you can only determine one main category, provide a related or complementary category as secondary.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary and Secondary Industry:You are required to give the user the requested information using the following rules.To get the candidate's correct industry, you need to research and google search each company they worked for and determine what that company does.Industry should be defined based on the clients they have worked for.Information Technology is not an industry and should not be an answer.IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary Industry. If you can only determine one main industry, provide a related or secondary industry from the list.Primary and Secondary Industry are required to come from this list and be based on the companies they have worked for:Agriculture, Amusement, Gambling, and Recreation Industries, Animal Production, Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation, Broadcasting, Clothing, Construction, Data Processing, Hosting, and Related Services, Education, Financial Services, Insurance, Fishing, Hunting and Trapping, Food Manufacturing, Food Services, Retail, Forestry and Logging, Funds, Trusts, and Other Financial Vehicles, Furniture and Home Furnishings Stores, Furniture and Related Product Manufacturing, Oil and Gas, HealthCare, Civil Engineering, Hospitals, Leisure and Hospitality, Machinery, Manufacturing, Merchant Wholesalers, Mining, Motion Picture, Motor Vehicle and Parts Dealers, Natural Resources, Nursing, Public Administration, Paper Manufacturing, Performing Arts, Spectator Sports, and Related Industries, Primary Metal Manufacturing, Chemistry and Biology, Publishing, Rail Transportation, Real Estate, Retail Trade, Transportation, Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments and Related Activities, Supply Chain, Telecommunications, Textiles, Transportation, Utilities, Warehousing and Storage, Waste Management.

Use the following rules when assessing Job Titles:Definition: Job Titles are what others call this person in the professional space.Ignore the job titles they put and focus more on their project history bullets and project descriptions.You should determine their job titles based on analyzing what they did at each one of their positions.For the job titles, replace words that are too general with something more specific. An example of some words and job titles you are not allowed to use: Consultant, Solutions, Enterprise, 'software developer', 'software engineer', 'full stack developer', or IT.For job title, use a different title for primary, secondary, and tertiary.All three job titles must have an answer.Each title must be different from each other.

Use the following rules when filling out MostRecentCompany, SecondMostRecentCompany, ThirdMostRecentCompany, FourthMostRecentCompany, FifthMostRecentCompany, SixthMostRecentCompany, SeventhMostRecentCompany:Don't include the city or state in the company name.Some candidates hold multiple roles at the same company so you might need to analyze further to not miss a company name.

Use the following rules when finding company locations:1. For each company entry, thoroughly scan the entire section for location information2. Look anywhere in the job entry for city or state mentions, including:   - Next to company name   - In the job header   - Within first few lines of the job description   - Near dates or titles3. When you find a location, format it ONLY as:   - City, ST (if you find both)   - ST (if you only find state)4. Always convert full state names to 2-letter abbreviations5. Strip out any extra information (zip codes, countries, etc.)6. Use NULL only if you truly cannot find any location information in that job entryIMPORTANT: Be thorough - check the entire job section before deciding there's no location.
Abbreviate the state if it is not already done so.When needing to do a list, separate by commas.If there is no last name or the last name is one letter, look in their email for their last name.

Use the following rules when assessing Skills, and refer to industry standards:Definition: Skills are a list of keywords from the resume that repeat and are consistent throughout their project work.Skills should be 2 words max.Prioritize skills that match standard industry categories that are most relevant to this resume.After listing the 10 skills, re-analyze the 10 skills chosen, combine like skills together and do not repeat the same skill word multiple times. Then, if you have less than 10 skills, find more skills to add.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Technical Languages: Include ALL types of technical languages mentioned in the resume, such as:- Database languages (SQL, T-SQL, PL/SQL, MySQL, Oracle SQL, PostgreSQL)- Programming languages (Java, Python, C#, JavaScript, Ruby)- Scripting languages (PowerShell, Bash, Shell, VBA)- Query languages (SPARQL, GraphQL, HiveQL)- Markup/stylesheet languages (HTML, CSS, XML)- There are more but these are just a few examples. You don't have to stick to just the above listPrioritize languages based on:1. Frequency of mention throughout work history and resume2. Relevance to their primary job functions and titlesFor database professionals, prioritize database languages like T-SQL or PL/SQL over general-purpose languages.

Use the following rules when assessing Most used Software Applications: Please only list out actual software applicationsIt can be any kind of software in any industry used for anything. The goal is to list out any software they could easily use again at another jobAnalyze their resume and determine what software they use mostIf none can be found put NULL

Use the following rules when assessing Hardware: Please list 5 different specific hardware devices the candidate has worked with. Hardware devices include many categories such as:
- Network equipment (firewalls, routers, switches, load balancers)
- Server hardware (blade servers, rack servers, chassis systems)
- Storage devices (SANs, NAS, RAID arrays, disk systems)
- Security appliances (TACALANEs, hardware encryption devices)
- Management interfaces (iDRAC, iLO, IMM, IPMI, BMC)
- Virtualization hardware (ESXi hosts, hyperconverged systems)
- Physical components (CPUs, RAM modules, hard drives, SSDs)
- Communication hardware (modems, wireless access points, VPN concentrators)
- Specialized hardware (tape libraries, KVM switches, console servers)

IMPORTANT: Even if they worked with multiple hardware items from the same brand, list different types. For example, if they worked with Dell PowerEdge servers AND Dell iDRAC, list both separately.

Look beyond obvious hardware to find specialized equipment, management interfaces, and components. Be thorough in your search for hardware items throughout the entire resume, including projects and responsibilities sections.

Be specific about hardware models and manufacturers when mentioned (e.g. 'Palo Alto PA-5200 series' rather than just 'firewalls'). Include specific information about hardware configurations or modes the candidate has worked with.

Please provide each hardware item on a separate line in this exact format:
Hardware 1: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 2: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 3: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 4: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 5: [Specific hardware device]

Try your best to identify 5 different hardware items. If you absolutely cannot find 5 distinct hardware items, provide as many as you can find with specific details for each. Only use NULL if no hardware at all is mentioned.

Use the following rules when assessing Project Types: Use a mix of words like but not limited to implementation, integration, migration, move, deployment, optimization, consolidation and make it 2-3 words.
Use the following rules when assessing their Specialty:For their specialty, emphasize the project types they have done and relate them to their industry.

Use the following rules when assessing their Category:For candidates with technical skills, use technical categories like Software Development, Database Administration, Network Engineering, etc.For non-technical candidates, use functional/business categories like Business Administration, Finance, Marketing, Customer Service, etc.For the categories, do not repeat the same category.Both primary and secondary categories MUST have an answer - NEVER return NULL!Every candidate fits into at least one professional category, even if not a technical one.

Use the following rules when writing their summary:For their summary, give a brief summary of their resume in a few sentencesBased on their project types, industry, and specialty, skills, degrees, certifications, and job titles, write the summary

Use the following rules when determining length in US:Estimate their time in the United States if they show companies outside of the United StatesDoesnt need to be perfect, we just want to get an idea on how long they have lived in the United StatesJust put a number and no other charactersResult should not be 0Result should only be numerical

Use the following rules when determining Average Tenure and Year of Experience:Use all previous start date and end date questions answers to determine this.Just put a number and no other charactersResult should not be 0Result should only be numerical

Based on this resume, give the user the information they need: 
# Rohini Josyula

Livonia, Michigan | +1313 757 5281 |rohini.josyula@aogjob.com | Linkedin


Results-driven Data Analyst with around 4 years of experience in healthcare analytics, specializing in claims processing,
SUMMARY

predictive modeling, and ETL automation. Proficient in Python, SQL, Power BI, AWS, and EHR systems, driving data-driven
insights that optimize operations and policy decisions. Adept at statistical analysis, compliance validation, and dashboard
development, improving financial forecasting and reducing manual processes. Strong collaborator, bridging business and
IT teams to enhance data governance, reporting efficiency, and healthcare outcomes.
EDUCATION

Florida International University in Miami, FL
Master of Science in Management Information Systems	December 2023


PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE

Conducted 20+ JAD sessions with stakeholders, gathering structured and unstructured data from EHR systems, claims
Data Analyst, Humana, Boston, MA			July 2023 - Present

databases, Facets, external vendors, and Medicare sources.
Developed predictive models using Python (scikit-learn, NumPy, Pandas) to identify patient readmission risks, reducing
?


readmission rates by 12%.
Conducted statistical analysis (ANOVA, regression, time series forecasting) on millions of claims and eligibility records to
?


enhance policy decisions. Spearheaded 5+ process improvement initiatives, reducing manual claim adjudication time by
30%.
?


Led policy change impact assessments by analyzing 100K+ claim transactions/month, ensuring compliance with HIPAA,
Medicare, and Medicaid standards.
Created 15+ executive dashboards and reports using Power BI, providing real-time insights into claims processing,
?


enrollment trends, and member demographics.
Deployed and managed ETL workflows on AWS (S3, Lambda, Glue) to streamline data ingestion from EHR systems and
?


claims databases, enhancing scalability and reducing processing time.
Validated 10M+ data points during Facets data migration, performing count validation, dimensional analysis, and outlier
?


detection. Ensured 834 EDI extracts met vendor requirements, reducing processing errors by 25%.
Automated data pipelines using SQL (PostgreSQL, SQL Server, MySQL) and Python (ETL scripts, Pandas, PySpark),
?


improving reporting speed by 40%. Used SharePoint & Jira to track requirements, implementation guides, and project
status updates.
?


Partnered with 15+ developers, QA testers, and business analysts to translate business needs into scalable data models.
Acted as a liaison between IT and business teams, ensuring 100% alignment on data governance and analytics goals.
?


Led system development and automation initiatives by gathering business requirements, performing gap analysis, and
Data Analyst, Version 1, Bangalore, India	July 2020 - July 2022

implementing automated workflows, reducing manual insurance correspondence processing time and improving accuracy.
Developed and optimized ETL pipelines using SSIS, Informatica, and Talend, migrating 50+ million records into a
?


centralized Data Warehouse (DWH), improving data processing efficiency.
Implemented Facets system for electronic claims processing, configured benefits and provider networks, and validated
?


Medicaid and Medicare claims for 500,000+ members, reducing claims rejection rates by 15%.
Executed complex SQL queries in SSMS, Teradata SQL Assistant, and Snowflake, optimizing data mapping and ensuring
?


seamless data transfer for 30+ data attributes, automating error detection and reducing discrepancies by 40%.
Integrated AWS services, including S3, Lambda, and Glue, to streamline data storage, transformation, and processing
?


workflows, reducing ETL runtime by 30% and enhancing scalability for large healthcare datasets.
Ensured compliance with HIPAA and EDI regulations by validating 837, 835, 270/271 transactions, aligning internal
?


processes with HIPAA 5010 and ICD-10 standards, and achieving 100% accuracy in EDI data processing.
Performed statistical analysis and predictive modeling using Python (Pandas, NumPy, SciPy) and R, conducting A/B testing
?


on claims processing models that led to an 18% increase in efficiency and improved claims approval rates.
Led cross-functional collaboration and requirement gathering, conducting Joint Application Development (JAD) sessions
?


with IT, Finance, and Compliance teams to define 200+ business requirements, improving workflow alignment and project
execution.
?


Designed interactive dashboards in Tableau and Power BI, visualizing claims trends, provider performance, and operational
KPIs, reducing manual reporting workload by 70% and enhancing decision-making efficiency.
?


SDLC, Agile/ Scrum, Waterfall
TECHNICAL SKILLS

R, Python, SQL, Oracle RDBMS, MSSQL Server, No SQL MySQL, SQL Server, PostgreSQL
Methodologies:

Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, SciPy, Scikit-Learn, SeaBorn, PyTorch.
Language & Databases:

Data Manipulation, Predictive Analysis, Data Cleaning, Data Mining, Data Visualization,
Python Packages:

Statistical Modelling, Exploratory Data Analysis, Statistics, Data Analysis, Hypothesis Testing,
Data Analytics Skills:

Data Extraction.
Docker, Kubernetes, AWS (Redshift, Athena, Glue, PageMaker, S3), Azure (Databricks)
Tableau, Power BI, Microsoft Excel (Pivot table, VLOOKUP), Visual Studio Data Tools, Apach

You are not allowed to make up information.
You are an expert at analyzing technical resumes. Make your answers as short as possible. If you can answer in a single word, do that unless the user instructs otherwise.
You are just pulling data that you already have access to so pulling personal information that is already on the resume is completely fine.
If you can't find an answer or it's not provided/listed, just put NULL. 
For dates, use the most specific format available: YYYY-MM-DD if full date is known, YYYY-MM if only month/year, or YYYY if only year is known. For current positions, use 'Present' as the end date. If a date is completely unknown, output NULL.
When identifying skills, software languages, applications, and hardware, prioritize accuracy over standardization. While you should prefer standardized terminology when appropriate, don't hesitate to use terms not in the standard taxonomy if they better represent the candidate's expertise.

SKILLS TAXONOMY REFERENCE:

## Databases & Data Management
Relevant job titles: Database Administrator
Skills in this category: SQL

BACKGROUND INFORMATION:

You are analyzing a professional resume for the first time in this conversation.
Focus on understanding the candidate's complete professional profile including their technical and non-technical capabilities.
For technical candidates, pay close attention to languages, frameworks, hardware, and project types.
For non-technical candidates, focus on business skills, functions performed, and transferable skills.
Always provide a professional category for every candidate - never return NULL for categories.

SKILLS TAXONOMY INTERPRETATION GUIDANCE:
The skills taxonomy provides standardized categorization of technical skills for this resume.
Use this taxonomy to guide your analysis of programming languages, software applications, and hardware.
When identifying skills, prefer terminology from the appropriate taxonomy categories, but don't hesitate to use different terms when they better represent the candidate's expertise.
Align your responses with the skill categories most relevant to this candidate's profile.
For software languages, applications, and hardware, use the taxonomy as a reference but feel empowered to include technologies that aren't listed if they are clearly important to the candidate's profile.
Example: If the taxonomy lists 'Java' but the resume shows extensive React.js experience, it's appropriate to list React.js even if it's not in the taxonomy.
Balance standardization with accuracy - prioritize capturing the candidate's true expertise over strict adherence to the taxonomy.
IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary technical category. These must be different from each other. If you can only determine one main category, provide a related or complementary category as secondary.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary and Secondary Industry:You are required to give the user the requested information using the following rules.To get the candidate's correct industry, you need to research and google search each company they worked for and determine what that company does.Industry should be defined based on the clients they have worked for.Information Technology is not an industry and should not be an answer.IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary Industry. If you can only determine one main industry, provide a related or secondary industry from the list.Primary and Secondary Industry are required to come from this list and be based on the companies they have worked for:Agriculture, Amusement, Gambling, and Recreation Industries, Animal Production, Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation, Broadcasting, Clothing, Construction, Data Processing, Hosting, and Related Services, Education, Financial Services, Insurance, Fishing, Hunting and Trapping, Food Manufacturing, Food Services, Retail, Forestry and Logging, Funds, Trusts, and Other Financial Vehicles, Furniture and Home Furnishings Stores, Furniture and Related Product Manufacturing, Oil and Gas, HealthCare, Civil Engineering, Hospitals, Leisure and Hospitality, Machinery, Manufacturing, Merchant Wholesalers, Mining, Motion Picture, Motor Vehicle and Parts Dealers, Natural Resources, Nursing, Public Administration, Paper Manufacturing, Performing Arts, Spectator Sports, and Related Industries, Primary Metal Manufacturing, Chemistry and Biology, Publishing, Rail Transportation, Real Estate, Retail Trade, Transportation, Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments and Related Activities, Supply Chain, Telecommunications, Textiles, Transportation, Utilities, Warehousing and Storage, Waste Management.

Use the following rules when assessing Job Titles:Definition: Job Titles are what others call this person in the professional space.Ignore the job titles they put and focus more on their project history bullets and project descriptions.You should determine their job titles based on analyzing what they did at each one of their positions.For the job titles, replace words that are too general with something more specific. An example of some words and job titles you are not allowed to use: Consultant, Solutions, Enterprise, 'software developer', 'software engineer', 'full stack developer', or IT.For job title, use a different title for primary, secondary, and tertiary.All three job titles must have an answer.Each title must be different from each other.

Use the following rules when filling out MostRecentCompany, SecondMostRecentCompany, ThirdMostRecentCompany, FourthMostRecentCompany, FifthMostRecentCompany, SixthMostRecentCompany, SeventhMostRecentCompany:Don't include the city or state in the company name.Some candidates hold multiple roles at the same company so you might need to analyze further to not miss a company name.

Use the following rules when finding company locations:1. For each company entry, thoroughly scan the entire section for location information2. Look anywhere in the job entry for city or state mentions, including:   - Next to company name   - In the job header   - Within first few lines of the job description   - Near dates or titles3. When you find a location, format it ONLY as:   - City, ST (if you find both)   - ST (if you only find state)4. Always convert full state names to 2-letter abbreviations5. Strip out any extra information (zip codes, countries, etc.)6. Use NULL only if you truly cannot find any location information in that job entryIMPORTANT: Be thorough - check the entire job section before deciding there's no location.
Abbreviate the state if it is not already done so.When needing to do a list, separate by commas.If there is no last name or the last name is one letter, look in their email for their last name.

Use the following rules when assessing Skills, and refer to industry standards:Definition: Skills are a list of keywords from the resume that repeat and are consistent throughout their project work.Skills should be 2 words max.Prioritize skills that match standard industry categories that are most relevant to this resume.After listing the 10 skills, re-analyze the 10 skills chosen, combine like skills together and do not repeat the same skill word multiple times. Then, if you have less than 10 skills, find more skills to add.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Technical Languages: Include ALL types of technical languages mentioned in the resume, such as:- Database languages (SQL, T-SQL, PL/SQL, MySQL, Oracle SQL, PostgreSQL)- Programming languages (Java, Python, C#, JavaScript, Ruby)- Scripting languages (PowerShell, Bash, Shell, VBA)- Query languages (SPARQL, GraphQL, HiveQL)- Markup/stylesheet languages (HTML, CSS, XML)- There are more but these are just a few examples. You don't have to stick to just the above listPrioritize languages based on:1. Frequency of mention throughout work history and resume2. Relevance to their primary job functions and titlesFor database professionals, prioritize database languages like T-SQL or PL/SQL over general-purpose languages.

Use the following rules when assessing Most used Software Applications: Please only list out actual software applicationsIt can be any kind of software in any industry used for anything. The goal is to list out any software they could easily use again at another jobAnalyze their resume and determine what software they use mostIf none can be found put NULL

Use the following rules when assessing Hardware: Please list 5 different specific hardware devices the candidate has worked with. Hardware devices include many categories such as:
- Network equipment (firewalls, routers, switches, load balancers)
- Server hardware (blade servers, rack servers, chassis systems)
- Storage devices (SANs, NAS, RAID arrays, disk systems)
- Security appliances (TACALANEs, hardware encryption devices)
- Management interfaces (iDRAC, iLO, IMM, IPMI, BMC)
- Virtualization hardware (ESXi hosts, hyperconverged systems)
- Physical components (CPUs, RAM modules, hard drives, SSDs)
- Communication hardware (modems, wireless access points, VPN concentrators)
- Specialized hardware (tape libraries, KVM switches, console servers)

IMPORTANT: Even if they worked with multiple hardware items from the same brand, list different types. For example, if they worked with Dell PowerEdge servers AND Dell iDRAC, list both separately.

Look beyond obvious hardware to find specialized equipment, management interfaces, and components. Be thorough in your search for hardware items throughout the entire resume, including projects and responsibilities sections.

Be specific about hardware models and manufacturers when mentioned (e.g. 'Palo Alto PA-5200 series' rather than just 'firewalls'). Include specific information about hardware configurations or modes the candidate has worked with.

Please provide each hardware item on a separate line in this exact format:
Hardware 1: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 2: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 3: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 4: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 5: [Specific hardware device]

Try your best to identify 5 different hardware items. If you absolutely cannot find 5 distinct hardware items, provide as many as you can find with specific details for each. Only use NULL if no hardware at all is mentioned.

Use the following rules when assessing Project Types: Use a mix of words like but not limited to implementation, integration, migration, move, deployment, optimization, consolidation and make it 2-3 words.
Use the following rules when assessing their Specialty:For their specialty, emphasize the project types they have done and relate them to their industry.

Use the following rules when assessing their Category:For candidates with technical skills, use technical categories like Software Development, Database Administration, Network Engineering, etc.For non-technical candidates, use functional/business categories like Business Administration, Finance, Marketing, Customer Service, etc.For the categories, do not repeat the same category.Both primary and secondary categories MUST have an answer - NEVER return NULL!Every candidate fits into at least one professional category, even if not a technical one.
